docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton's Medicare reform plan, if approved by Congress, would constitute the most substantial change to Medicare since its creation in 1965. Although no reform can instantly improve quality and increase cost-efficiency in the enormous program, Mr. Clinton has delivered a well-considered proposal that can shore up Medicare without heedlessly expanding costs or creating chaos for 39 million beneficiaries. The plan takes a prudent, incremental approach in adding benefits and changing Medicare's structure. The proposal is premised on putting $794 billion into Medicare over the next 15 years from the projected $5.5 trillion Federal surplus. But any plan that does not greatly cut benefits or reduce eligibility through income tests or other means would need to put more money into Medicare in the next two decades as baby boomers reach retirement and technology makes it possible for more people to live longer. The Clinton plan would extend the solvency of the Medicare trust fund to 2027.
docs.abstract: Editorial lauds Pres Clinton's Medicare reform plan; holds it takes prudent, incremental approach in adding benefits and changing Medicare's structure
docs.snippet: President Clinton's Medicare reform plan, if approved by Congress, would constitute the most substantial change to Medicare since its creation in 1965. Although no reform can instantly improve quality and increase cost-efficiency in the enormous...

docs.lead_paragraph: Following up on a promise to preserve Medicare for the aging baby-boom generation, President Clinton today proposed fundamental changes in the program's structure to make it more like private health insurance and to add coverage of prescription drugs, a benefit long sought by the elderly. The White House said his proposal, one of the biggest domestic policy initiatives of the last three decades, would help keep Medicare solvent until 2027 -- 12 years longer than the last official projections under current law.

headline.main: CLINTON LAYS OUT PLAN TO OVERHAUL MEDICARE SYSTEM

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton, following up on pledge to preserve Medicare, proposes basic structural changes to make program more like private health insurance and to add coverage of prescription drugs; holds proposal will help keep Medicare solvent until 2027; plan calls for cost savings, rise in some costs to beneficiaries and infusion of $794 billion from Treasury over 15 years; calls for coverage of half of drug costs, initially limited to $1000 a year, for small, optional premium; both benefit and premium would rise over time; people with low incomes would not have to pay premium or beneficiary's half of drug costs; Congressional Republicans react cautiously, holding they too want to restructure Medicare, but fear costs of proposed drug benefit would soar; table of proposals; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Following up on a promise to preserve Medicare for the aging baby-boom generation, President Clinton today proposed fundamental changes in the program's structure to make it more like private health insurance and to add coverage of prescription...

docs.lead_paragraph: Infuriating many Democrats, the White House today reached a basic agreement with Republicans in Congress on legislation to limit lawsuits arising from Year 2000 computer breakdowns. Republican leaders said all the main points had been settled and that they hoped Congress would clear the measure for the President's signature this week. The White House agreed that only technical language remained to be worked out.

headline.main: Vexing Party, Clinton Backs Year 2000 Bill

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton, angering many Democrats, reaches basic accord with Congressional Republicans on bill to limit suits arising from Year 2000 computer breakdowns; Administration spokesman says relatively minor changes enable Clinton to agree to bill he earlier vowed to veto; bill would set ceiling on punitive damages against small companies, give all companies grace period to fix breakdowns, sharply limit class-action suits and protect wealthy companies against being held liable for computer failures caused by poorer ones (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After more than a week of intense partisan feuding that plunged the Senate into paralysis, Republicans and Democrats reached an agreement late today on how and when to consider legislation to give patients new guarantees from their health insurance plans. The decision cleared the way for the Senate to pass several spending bills held captive by the logjam, and it set the stage for four full days of debate and votes in mid-July on an issue that promises to be every bit as contentious as were new restrictions on firearms.

headline.main: Senate Agrees on Framework To Weigh Patient's Rights Bill

docs.abstract: Senate Republicans and Democrats agree to four-day mid-July debate on bill to give patients new guarantees from their health insurance plans, ending over week of intense partisan feuding; Democrats forced Republican concessions on issue by using parliamentary tactics to paralyze Senate (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Viagra, it turns out, has a political side effect. Last year's anti-impotence sensation has led to this year's byproduct: Around the country, more than a half-dozen state legislatures, swayed largely by insurers' coverage of Viagra treatment, have recently passed measures requiring carriers that cover prescription drugs to pay for women's contraceptives as well. More states are expected to follow.

headline.main: Insurance for Viagra Spurs Coverage for Birth Control

docs.abstract: New Hampshire Legislature becomes latest of state legislatures around nation, swayed largely by insurers' coverage of Viagra treatment for male impotence, to require carriers that cover prescription drugs to pay for women's contraceptives as well; more states are expected to follow, with 'contraceptive equity' bills introduced in over 30 states; experts say speedy success of so many contraception bills also reflects rising power of women in state legislatures (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Serbs Protest Milosevic In a Devastated City About 10,000 people packed the central square of Cacak, a war-damaged manufacturing city in Serbia that is controlled by the opposition, to demand the resignation of President Slobodan Milosevic. Speakers said he had shamed Serbia, ruined the economy and tried to cover up his failures with a campaign of lies. A1 NATO troops mistakenly detained two top commanders of the Kosovo Liberation Army, believing that they were in violation of the demilitarization agreement. A10

docs.lead_paragraph: A poll released yesterday by Rutgers University shows that 73 percent of eligible families are aware of New Jersey's subsidized insurance program for children, but only 35,000 of the state's 95,000 eligible children are enrolled. Tomorrow, the state plans to expand eligibility for the program, known as Kidcare, to 60,000 more children, by raising the income limit of the Federal poverty level to 350 percent, which is $58,000 a year for a family of four. Eligibility has been limited to families earning up to 200 percent of the poverty level, or $33,000.

headline.main: Poll Says Many Children Don't Use Insurance Plan

docs.lead_paragraph: Kroll Business Consultant Provided Access to Famous Martin R. Frankel, the man the authorities suspect of siphoning more than $300 million from a string of insurance companies, gained access to powerful people with the help of a business consultant, Thomas J. Corbally. Mr. Corbally was an insider at Kroll Associates, one of America's best-known private investigative agencies, having worked closely with Jules B. Kroll for almost 20 years and having an office at the firm's Manhattan headquarters. [Page A1.]

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton laid out his proposal today to use the fast-growing Federal budget surplus to eliminate the national debt while shoring up Social Security and Medicare, and left open the possibility of a deal with the Republican-led Congress over its demand for big tax cuts. The plan could set the stage for a grand compromise with Republicans encompassing new spending on the military and social programs as well as tax cuts and the fate of the two giant retirement-security programs. Or it could just as easily lead to a hardening of positions and a bitter struggle extending into the 2000 elections.

headline.main: CLINTON OUTLINES PLAN FOR SURPLUS; G.O.P. SUSPICIOUS
headline.kicker: PLANNING FOR A SURPLUS: THE OVERVIEW

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton lays out proposal to use fast-growing Federal budget surplus to eliminate national debt while shoring up Social Security and Medicare, and leaves open possibility of deal with Republican-led Congress over its demands for big tax cuts; says surplus will be 20 percent higher over next 10 years than projected five months ago, with total anticipated to be cumulative $2.93 trillion, and will be more than $1 trillion over 15 years; says surplus is hard-earned product of fiscal discipline and should be used to prepare for great challenges facing country; Republicans, who plan push to pass $775 billion, 10-year tax cut in face of veto threat, welcome news of growing surplus and are heartened about some aspects of Clinton proposal; remain suspicious of Clinton, who has repeatedly bested them in budget politics and like them is torn between desire for bipartisan deal and party's need for potent campaign issues; chart; photo (M)
docs.snippet: President Clinton laid out his proposal today to use the fast-growing Federal budget surplus to eliminate the national debt while shoring up Social Security and Medicare, and left open the possibility of a deal with the Republican-led Congress over...

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 Some Drug Aid to Kosovo Is Criticized as Useless The World Health Organization said about a third to half of all of shipments of corporate drug aid were inappropriate and likely to gather dust in warehouses or have to be destroyed at government expense. Items deemed to be of marginal use included lip balm, hemorrhoid ointment and anti-smoking inhalers. A1 About a quarter of the Serbs in Kosovo -- more than 75,000 -- have fled the province in the 18 days since Serbian forces began pulling out, the Yugoslav Red Cross said. A8
